title: GOP moves closer to votes on eliminating state treasurer
text:
GOP moves closer to votes on eliminating state treasurer Journal Sentinel files The office of state treasurer, now held by Matt Adamczyk (left) would be eliminated under a constitutional amendment proposed by Republican lawmakers. The office of state secretary of state, now held by Doug La Follette (right), would not be changed. By Jason Stein of the Journal Sentinel Updated: 2:39 p.m. (3) Comments 
Madison — After years of trying , Republicans are coming closer to a long held goal — giving voters a chance to eliminate the office of state treasurer. 
The state Assembly will take the first step Tuesday toward a proposed constitutional amendment eliminating the office, which has already been relieved of most of its responsibilities. 
The state treasurer's office had one of its last major responsibilities — authority of the state's unclaimed property program — eliminated under the state budget two years ago and has lost many other responsibilities over the years, such as responsibility for the state college savings program. 
Rep. Michael Schraa (R-Oshkosh), the proposal's sponsor, noted that GOP Treasurer Matt Adamczyk and his predecessor Kurt Schuller both campaigned in 2014 and in 2010 on eliminating the position. 
"It's a do-nothing job," Schraa said. "It's symbolic." 
In the past Republican lawmakers have also sought to eliminate the job of longtime Secretary of State Doug La Follette, a Democrat. La Follette has argued for keeping his job, saying that elected officials are more responsive to the public, and the current proposal leaves La Follette alone and affects only the treasurer. 
Eliminating the position requires a constitutional amendment, which would have to pass through two consecutive sessions of the Legislature and receive voter approval in a referendum. The earliest the Wisconsin Constitution could be changed is 2017. 
Both Adamczyk and La Follette both serve on the Board of Commissioners of Public Lands, one of their few remaining responsibilities and one that is also spelled out in the state constitution. Along with state Attorney General Brad Schimel, the men oversee an agency that manages some state lands and $1 billion in assets, with the interest going to benefit public school libraries in the state. 
The proposal would replace Adamczyk on the board with Lt. Gov. Rebecca Kleefisch, a Republican. © 2015 , Journal Sentinel Inc. All rights reserved. About Jason Stein 
Jason Stein covers the state Capitol and is the author with his colleague Patrick Marley of "More than They Bargained For: Scott Walker, Unions and the Fight for Wisconsin." His work has been recognized by journalism groups such as the American Society of News Editors, the Society of American Business Editors and Writers, and the Association of Capitol Reporters and Editors.
